metadata.case_name: Non-resident Bank v. Income Tax Authorities

facts.text: Appellant is a non-resident Bank incorporated under the National Bank Act of the United States of America with head office there and branches worldwide including India.
Assessed under Business Profits Tax Act, 1947 for chargeable accounting periods: 1-4-1946 to 24-12-1946; 25-12-1946 to 24-12-1947; 25-12-1947 to 23-12-1948; 24-12-1948 to 31-3-1949.
Balance Sheet as on December 31, 1946: Capital 77,500,000; Surplus 152,500,000; Undivided Profit 29,534,614.21.

Directors' Report dated January 14, 1947: Surplus increased to 152,500,000 by transfer of 10,000,000 from Undivided Profits; Undivided Profits after transfer 29,534,614 (increase of 240,376 from prior year).
Balance Sheet of 1948 shows capital funds increased from 169,768 thousands in 1939 to 320,795 thousands; Surplus from 62,500 to 182,500 thousands; Undivided Profits from 19,768 to 50,795 thousands.
Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner excluded Undivided Profits in computing capital under R. 2(1) of Schedule II.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal dismissed appellant's appeal, holding Undivided Profits are balance of profit and loss account.
Tribunal referred question to Bombay High Court: Whether Undivided Profits of 29,534,614.21 as of Dec 31, 1946 can be treated as reserves under R. 2(1) Sch II for period 25-12-1946 to 24-12-1947.
Bombay High Court (judgment Feb 5, 1957) held Undivided Profits not reserves, no transfer to reserve or act of volition by Directors except 10M to Surplus; cited Century Spinning.
US Treasury Rules under s.5211 Revised Statutes (Title 12 USC 161): Capital account items 25-28: 25 Capital, 26 Surplus, 27 Undivided Profits, 28 Reserves; Item 29 Total capital accounts.

Letter from Deputy Controller of Currency, Washington: Undivided Profits part of capital funds, integral to capital structure; used for continuous business use, charged losses against it; not like undistributed profits in India.
US banking accounting: Each year's account self-contained, residue to Undivided Profits as part of capital fund; losses drawn from it then Surplus.

legal_issues.text: Meaning of the word 'reserves' in R. 2(1) of Schedule II of the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947, and whether Undivided Profits of the appellant Bank qualify as reserves for computing capital for abatement.

petitioner_arguments.text: Undivided Profits fall within 'reserves' under R. 2(1) Sch II; part of capital funds per US Treasury Rules, Directors' reports, and letter from Deputy Controller.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: R. 2(1) Schedule II, Business Profits Tax Act, 1947; US Treasury Rules s.5211 Revised Statutes

petitioner_arguments.text: Difference in US vs Indian banking accounting: US treats Undivided Profits as accumulated residues for capital, not mere P&L carry forward.

respondent_arguments.text: Undivided Profits are not reserves but equivalent to balance of profit and loss account; no distinction based on US nomenclature.
No act of volition by Directors to transfer to reserves; only 10M transferred to Surplus.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Century Spinning & Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. CIT

court_reasoning.text: US accounting differs from Indian: Undivided Profits are required by law, integral part of capital funds for continuous business use, charged losses against; not mere undistributed profits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Failure to appreciate US accounting difference led Tribunal and HC to error.

court_reasoning.text: Applies test from Century Spinning: True nature by substance; here, required by US statute/rules, part of capital structure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Undivided Profits are reserves as set apart after provisions for continuous use.

court_reasoning.text: Cites US Supreme Court in Fidelity case: Undivided Profits part of capital employed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Designation as Undivided Profits has no legal significance for tax on capital use.

holdings.text: Undivided Profits designated in Balance Sheet are part of reserves and must be included in computing capital under R. 2(1) Sch II for chargeable periods.

precedents_cited.case_name: Century Spinning & Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. CIT, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for 'reserves': true nature by substance, must be kept back by directors for future purpose.

precedents_cited.case_name: Fidelity Title and Trust Co. v. United States
precedents_cited.relevance: Undivided Profits are part of capital employed in banking for tax purposes.

statutes_cited.name: Business Profits Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines computation of capital as paid-up share capital plus reserves (not allowed in I.T. profits), for abatement.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reserves insofar as not allowed in computing profits under this Act.

statutes_cited.name: US Revised Statutes
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires specific allocation in National Banks' reports of condition, including Undivided Profits as capital account item.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; question referred by Tribunal answered in affirmative in favour of appellant; Undivided Profits to be added to capital as reserves under R. 2(1) Sch II for chargeable accounting periods.
outcome.relief_granted: Inclusion of Undivided Profits in capital computation for abatement under Business Profits Tax Act.

key_quotes.text: "The term Undivided Profits simply follows a bank accounting nomenclature used in the United States to designate profits set aside, after provisions for expenses and taxes, dividends and reserves, for continuous future use in the business of the bank"
key_quotes.speaker: Deputy Controller of Currency (quoted by court)
key_quotes.significance: Explains nature of Undivided Profits as part of capital funds per US practice.

key_quotes.text: "A reserve in the sense in which it is used in rule 2 can only mean profit earned by a company and not distributed as dividend to the shareholders but kept back by the directors for any purpose to which it may be put in future."
key_quotes.speaker: court (quoting Century Spinning)
key_quotes.significance: Test applied to hold Undivided Profits as reserves.

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion therefore the amount designated as Undivided Profits is a part of the reserves and has to be taken into account when computing the capital and reserves within R. 2(1) of Schedule II of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
